data.question: What is the maximum Faradaic efficiency (FE) achieved by the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework incorporated with enzyme-mimicking nickel bis(dithiolene) ligand for CO2 electroreduction?
How does the electrocatalytic performance of the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework compare to the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand in terms of FE for HCOO–?
data.answer: The In(III) Metal–Organic Framework shows a significantly enhanced performance with FE for HCOO– increasing from 54.7% to 89.6% compared to the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand.

data.question: Is the electrical conductivity of the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework higher than that of the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand?
What role does the [NiS4] site play in the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction process?
data.answer: The [NiS4] site serves as a CO2 binding site and efficient catalytic center, mimicking the active sites of formate dehydrogenase and CO-dehydrogenase.

data.question: What is the effect of incorporating nickel bis(dithiolene) ligand on the MOF's electrochemical surface area (ECSA)?
data.answer: Incorporating nickel bis(dithiolene) ligand results in a higher electrochemical surface area (ECSA) for the MOF.

data.question: Does the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework maintain its structural integrity after electrocatalysis?
What is the significance of the turnover frequency (TOF) values obtained for the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework and its comparison to the isomorphic MOF?
data.answer: The TOF values indicate the per-site activity of the electrocatalysts, with the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework showing superior catalytic activity compared to the isomorphic MOF.

data.question: How does the CO2 adsorption capacity of the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework compare to the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand?
data.answer: The In(III) Metal–Organic Framework has a significantly larger CO2 adsorption capacity compared to the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand.

data.question: Is the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework more thermally stable than the isomorphic MOF with TTFTB ligand?
What is the role of the [NiS4] site in enhancing the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance of the In(III) Metal–Organic Framework?
data.answer: The [NiS4] site enhances the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction performance by serving as an efficient CO2 binding and catalytic site, leading to a higher conversion rate and Faradaic efficiency.
